column1: #text=Sometimes I buy books but more often I just decide to borrow one from the public library because you can read them and take them back and it does n't cost you anything .
#text=Most libraries have a vast selection of books so you would never be unable to find something you wanted to read .
#text=A lot of libraries have their catalog online so you can check to see if they have a particular book before you go to the library .

#text=I recently had to join a new library so I went there and spoke to the lady behind the desk who asked me to fill in a form with my address and contact details , and provide proof of my identity .
#text=When I had finished filling in the form , I took it back to her and she made me a little plastic library card with my account number and my name on it , along with a unique barcode .
#text=She told me I had to use this card to check out books whenever I went to the library .
#text=There were thousands of books on hundreds of shelves , all of them are filed in some sort of order .

#text=Fiction books were filed by author surname , and non-fiction books were filed by a system called the Dewey decimal system which numbers books according to their subject classification and are then filed in that number order .
#text=The books were easy to find , there were computers around the library where you could check to see what books were available .

#text=When I had selected the books I wanted to borrow I went to one of the self service stations and scanned the barcode on the books and the barcode on my new library card , and the books were issued to me .
#text=I also got a printed receipt to show me when the books were due to be returned .
